prompt: Facts: Marriage between Om Prakash (Respondent No. 1/Accused) and Kamlesh (deceased) solemnized on 25.04.1988.; Kamlesh died due to burn injuries at her matrimonial home in Village Mandawara, District Nagaur, Rajasthan on 08.09.1988.; The death occurred within approximately 4.5 months of the marriage.; Initial report (Ex. P-3) lodged by Om Prakash suggested accidental death due to stove bursting while preparing tea.; Bhanwar Lal (PW-2, father of the deceased) lodged a First Information Report (FIR) (Ex. P-1) on 09.09.1988 alleging that his daughter was harassed for dowry (demand for TV and Fridge) and killed by her husband and in-laws.; Prosecution witnesses, including PW-2 (father), PW-4 (Smt. Kamla, mother), and PW-6 (Jetha Ram, uncle), testified about dowry demands and harassment meted out to Kamlesh soon after marriage.; PW-2 testified he visited Kamlesh at her matrimonial home and observed her distress, and the accused complained about insufficient dowry.; Post-mortem report (Ex. P-11) indicated death due to shock as a result of extensive (90%) ante-mortem burns. Kerosene smell was detected.; The Trial Court acquitted all accused (Om Prakash - husband, Mangi Lal - father-in-law, Surji Devi - mother-in-law), disbelieving the prosecution witnesses on dowry demands and considering the possibility of accident or suicide.; The High Court, on appeal by the State, reversed the acquittal. It convicted Om Prakash under Section 304B IPC and sentenced him to 7 years RI. It also convicted Om Prakash, Mangi Lal, and Surji Devi under Section 498A IPC and sentenced them to 2 years RI each. Sentences were concurrent.; The accused (Respondents herein) did not appeal the High Court judgment; this appeal was filed by the State of Rajasthan seeking enhancement of sentence or conviction under Section 302 IPC.; The Supreme Court primarily examined the correctness of the High Court's conviction based on the evidence, despite the appeal's focus being enhancement (implicitly reviewing the conviction itself). | IPC: Section 304B (Dowry Death), Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), Section 302 (Punishment for murder) - Considered but not applied by HC/SC for conviction., Section 113B, Indian Evidence Act, 1872 (Presumption as to dowry death)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The High Court correctly reversed the perverse acquittal by the Trial Court, as evidence clearly established dowry demand and cruelty soon before death.", "precedents": ["Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415 (Principles for appeal against acquittal)", "State of U.P. v. Banne @ Baijnath (2009) 4 SCC 271 (Reversal justified if trial court view is impossible or perverse)", "Dhananjay Chatterjee v. State of W.B. (1994) 2 SCC 220 (Appellate court's power to review evidence)"]}, {"argument": "All ingredients of Section 304B IPC were satisfied against Om Prakash: Unnatural death (burns) within 7 years (4.5 months) of marriage, preceded by dowry-related cruelty and harassment.", "precedents": ["Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207 ('Soon before' implies proximate and live link, not necessarily immediate)", "Satvir Singh v. State of Punjab (2001) 8 SCC 633 (Interpretation of S. 304B and S. 113B Evidence Act)", "Shamnsaheb M. Multtani v. State of Karnataka (2001) 2 SCC 577 (Essential ingredients of S. 304B)"]}, {"argument": "Evidence of persistent demands for TV/Fridge and consequent harassment proved cruelty under Section 498A against husband and in-laws.", "precedents": ["Girdhar Shankar Tawade v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 5 SCC 177 (Definition and scope of cruelty under S. 498A)", "State of Karnataka v. H.S. Srinivasa (2001) 4 SCC 505 (Testimony of close relatives regarding dowry demands is reliable)", "Gananath Pattnaik v. State of Orissa (2002) 2 SCC 619 (Mental cruelty sufficient for S. 498A)"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "The Trial Court's acquittal was well-reasoned, based on contradictions in prosecution evidence and plausible defence of accident or suicide.", "precedents": ["Arulvelu v. State (2009) 10 SCC 206 (Reversal of acquittal only if trial court findings are perverse or illegal)", "Basappa v. State of Karnataka (2014) 5 SCC 154 (High Court should be slow to disturb acquittal unless compelling reasons exist)", "Ramesh Babulal Doshi v. State of Gujarat (1996) 9 SCC 225 (Acquittal reversal requires glaring errors in trial court findings)"]}, {"argument": "Prosecution failed to establish a proximate and live link between alleged dowry demands/harassment and the death to satisfy the 'soon before death' requirement of Section 304B.", "precedents": ["Major Singh v. State of Punjab (2015) 5 SCC 201 (Emphasis on proximate link for 'soon before')", "Surinder Singh v. State of Haryana (2014) 4 SCC 129 (Temporal proximity is crucial)", "Tarsem Singh v. State of Punjab (2008) 16 SCC 155 (Need for cogent evidence linking cruelty and death proximately)"]}, {"argument": "The possibility of accidental death (stove burst) or suicide due to other reasons (e.g., difficulty adjusting to marital life, homesickness) was not ruled out by the prosecution.", "precedents": ["State of Punjab v. Iqbal Singh (1991) 3 SCC 1 (Prosecution must establish unnatural death linked to dowry cruelty)", "Sanju alias Sanjay Singh Sengar v. State of M.P. (2002) 5 SCC 371 (Distinction between abetment of suicide (S. 306) and dowry death (S. 304B); requires proof beyond doubt)", "Mangat Ram v. State of Haryana (2014) 12 SCC 595 (If suicide is a possibility, conviction under 304B requires strong evidence of preceding cruelty)"]}, {"argument": "Allegations against the in-laws (Mangi Lal, Surji Devi) under Section 498A were general and omnibus, lacking specific evidence of their individual involvement in cruelty.", "precedents": ["Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207 (Caution against implicating all family members routinely)", "Geeta Mehrotra v. State of U.P. (2012) 10 SCC 741 (Need for specific allegations against each accused relative in S. 498A cases)", "Bhaskar Lal Sharma v. Monica (2009) 10 SCC 604 (Court must ascertain specific roles of relatives)"]}]}
